mn60:3.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins called Sālā.
mn60:3.3: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard:
mn60:3.4: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
mn60:3.6: ‘That Blessed One is perfect, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
mn60:3.7: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
mn60:3.8: He teaches Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
mn60:3.9: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
mn60:3.10: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha.
mn60:3.11: Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their cupped palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
mn60:4.2: “So, householders, is there some other teacher you’re happy with, in whom you have acquired reasoned faith?”
mn60:5.1: “Since you haven’t found a teacher you’re happy with, you should undertake and implement this guaranteed teaching.
mn60:5.2: For when the guaranteed teaching is undertaken, it will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
mn60:5.3: And what is the guaranteed teaching?
mn60:6.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn60:6.2: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no duties to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
mn60:6.7: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.
mn60:6.9: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are duties to mother and father. There are beings reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are well attained and practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
mn60:6.16: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”
mn60:7.1: “Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that
mn60:7.2: there’s no meaning in giving, etc.
mn60:7.5: they will reject good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind,
mn60:7.6: and undertake and implement bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
mn60:7.9: Because those ascetics and brahmins don’t see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, depravity, and corruption, or that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.
mn60:7.10: Moreover, since there actually is another world, their view that there is no other world is wrong view.
mn60:7.12: Since there actually is another world, their thought that there is no other world is wrong thought.
mn60:7.14: Since there actually is another world, their speech that there is no other world is wrong speech.
mn60:7.16: Since there actually is another world, in saying that there is no other world
mn60:7.17: they contradict those perfected ones who know the other world.
mn60:7.18: Since there actually is another world, in persuading another that there is no other world
mn60:7.19: they are persuading them to accept an untrue teaching.
mn60:7.20: And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down.
mn60:7.21: So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct.
mn60:7.22: And that is how wrong view gives rise to these many bad, unskillful qualities—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.

mn60:8.2: ‘If there is no other world, when this individual’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe.
mn60:8.3: And if there is another world, when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:11.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn60:11.2: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
mn60:11.4: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
mn60:11.5: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
mn60:11.7: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
mn60:11.9: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’
mn60:11.10: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this. They say:
mn60:11.11: ‘The one who acts does a bad deed when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do a bad deed when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
mn60:11.13: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil.
mn60:11.14: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
mn60:11.16: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
mn60:11.18: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is merit and outcome of merit.’
mn60:11.19: What do you think, householders? Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

mn60:16.10: ‘There is a cause and condition for the corruption of sentient beings.

mn60:22.1: “A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way.
mn60:22.2: Some ascetics and brahmins say that
mn60:22.3: there are no totally formless meditations, but I have not seen that.
mn60:22.4: Some ascetics and brahmins say that
mn60:22.5: there are totally formless meditations, but I have not known that.
mn60:22.6: Without knowing or seeing, it would not be appropriate for me to take one side and declare:
mn60:22.7: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.’
mn60:22.8: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that
mn60:22.9: there are no totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible
mn60:22.10: that I will be guaranteed rebirth among the gods who possess form and made of mind.
mn60:22.11: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that
mn60:22.12: there are totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible
mn60:22.13: that I will be guaranteed rebirth among the gods who are formless and made of perception.
mn60:22.14: Now, owing to form, bad things are seen: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
mn60:22.15: But those things don’t exist where it is totally formless.
mn60:22.16: Reflecting like this, they simply practice for the disillusionment, fading away, and cessation of forms.

mn60:25.1: Householders, these four people are found in the world.
mn60:25.3: 1. One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
mn60:25.4: • One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
mn60:25.5: • One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
mn60:25.6: <li>One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
mn60:25.7: In the present life they live without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.
mn60:26.1: And what person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?
mn60:26.2: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. …
mn60:26.4: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of torturing and tormenting the body.
mn60:26.5: This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
mn60:27.1: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
mn60:27.2: It’s when a person is a butcher of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.
mn60:27.5: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
mn60:28.1: And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
mn60:28.2: It’s when a person is an anointed king or an affluent brahmin. …
mn60:28.4: His slaves, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping, with tearful faces.
mn60:28.5: This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
mn60:29.1: And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others,
mn60:29.2: living without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves?
mn60:29.3: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
mn60:29.4: A householder hears that Dharma, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some respectable family. …
mn60:29.5: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption …
mn60:30.1: When my mind had converged like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—they turn it toward recollection of past lives. …
mn60:30.5: They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
mn60:30.6: When their mind has unified in samādhi like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—they turn it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
mn60:30.7: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. …
mn60:30.9: They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
mn60:30.10: When their mind has converged like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—he turns it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
mn60:30.11: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
mn60:30.13: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
mn60:30.14: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
mn60:30.15: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
mn60:30.16: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
mn60:30.17: This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
mn60:30.18: They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”
mn60:31.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha:
mn60:31.3: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what is there—
mn60:31.4: Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
mn60:31.5: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn60:31.6: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
